Docs.summary: A callback function which GPGME calls if a key edit operation is on-going.
Docs.returns: A . If the returning value is not 0, the key editing procedure will be stopped. See "Remarks" for more information.

remarks.para: KeyEditCallback method must be overwritten by the inherited class.

It is the functions which GPGME calls if a key edit operation is on-going. The status code and the argument line are passed through by GPGME from the crypto engine. The int is 0 for normal status messages.
If indicates a command rather than a status message, the response to the command should be written to . The was provided by the user at start of operation .
The function should return 0 or an error value. If the returning value is not 0, GPGME will stop the key editing procedure and an error will be thrown.
If the KeyEditCallback method of the inherited class throws an exception during the callback, it will be saved in the attribute.

Docs.param: A that is used to perform the operation.
A object that contains necessary information for the (key-) signature deletion operation.
Docs.summary: Creates a (key-) signature revocation certificate and adds it to the list of (key-) signatures.
Docs.remarks:
The supplied context is locked during the editing operation. Make sure that the private keys are available for all (key-) signatures that shall be revoked.
You need to specify the number(s) of the requested (key-) signature(s) in . If you enumerate the list of (key-) signatures ( property) to count and identify the correct numbers - make sure that you DON'T count "revocation" signatures/certificates. You can check this with the property for each (key-) signature in the list.
Example:
# gpg --edit-key 321FEDCBA Command > check uid Mallory <mallory@home.internal> rev! ABCDEF123 2009-08-01 Alice <alice@home.internal> rev! ABCDEF123 2009-08-02 Alice <alice@home.internal> sig!3 321FEDCBA 2009-08-01 [self-signature] sig! ABCDEF123 2009-08-01 Alice <alice@home.internal>
There are four entries in this example list of (key-) signatures. The first two are "revocation signatures". That means the self-signature starts with number "1" and Alice's (key-)signature follows with number "2". (In this example, Alice created two revocation signatures/certificates. She created the first one on August 1st and the second one on August 2nd.)
